description: Introduces the basic terminology, concepts, and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Concepts will include revenue and expense recognition, accounts receivable, inventory, long-lived assets, liquidity and solvency. Explores the income statement, balance sheet, and statement of cash flows, often using reports filed by publicly traded companies. Includes online modules for instructional content. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Financial Accounting
subject: ACCT

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime? What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality? What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy? This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system. Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice. Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: AFAM

description: Although the global city is often considered a recent development, this course examines the long history of connections between the local space of American cities and larger global forces since the nineteenth century. We will explore how immigration, international commerce and exchange, tourism, real estate, and cultural spaces like museums and parks have made U.S. cities profoundly global spaces and how cities have been central to the history of the United States as a global power. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
short_title: United States Cities in a Glo...
title: United States Cities in a Global Age
subject: AMST

description: Introduction to the practical and ethical dilemmas that arise in the conduct of ethnographic research. Primary focus on deepening the student's understanding of the unique scholarly and moral perspective that meaningful ethnography depends on. Students will leave this course ready to conduct independent ethnographic research for senior projects using a variety of media. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Ethnographic Fieldwork:  Analysis and Practice
subject: AMST

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime? What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality? What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy? This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system. Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice. Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: AMST

description: A survey of the histories of both the Hollywood novel and films about Hollywood. Examination of the ways in which these two genres portray "the dream factory"—its past, its present, and its future—as well as the way they interact. Books include Harry Leon Wilson's Merton at the Movies, Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and I Should Have Stayed Home, F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star, and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
short_title: The Hollywood Novel and the H...
title: The Hollywood Novel and the Hollywood Movie
subject: AMST

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include films such as The Birth of a Nation, Gold Diggers of 1933, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: AMST

description: An introduction to the central ideas, methods, and debates that make up the anthropological study of human thought and behavior. Survey of dynamic ways of life in many different societies; outline of the ways anthropologists have tried to understand societies. Hands-on ethnographic research provides insight into how cultural anthropologists do what they do—what problems they encounter and what tools and techniques they use for research and analysis. Film screenings meet W 7-9pm. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: Introduction to human and primate evolution, primate behavior, and human biology. Topics include a review of principles of evolutionary and population biology, the evolution of primates and people, and current thinking about the evolution of human behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: Hands-on introduction to forensic anthropology, using laboratory training, lectures, and case studies. Introduction to basic skeletal anatomy and to the use of recovered skeletal materials to assess a deceased individual's age, sex, height, ancestry, time of death, bone trauma, and disease. Additional topics include techniques for recovering human skeletal remains, reconstruction of faces, genetic identification, and medicolegal contexts of forensic anthropology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Forensic Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to the earliest cities, states, and empires. Explores how these societies developed and why they collapsed. Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
short_title: The Genesis and Collapse of O...
title: The Genesis and Collapse of Old World Civilizations
subject: ANTH

description: Introduction to the patterns and processes of human genetic variation. Topics covered include: human origins and migration; molecular adaptations to environment, lifestyle, and disease; ancient and forensic DNA analyses; and genealogical reconstructions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Molecular Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: Introduction to the practical and ethical dilemmas that arise in the conduct of ethnographic research. Primary focus on deepening the student's understanding of the unique scholarly and moral perspective that meaningful ethnography depends on. Students will leave this course ready to conduct independent ethnographic research for senior projects using a variety of media. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Ethnographic Fieldwork:  Analysis and Practice
subject: ANTH

description: Offered in Singapore. Southeast Asia in Context is a five-week thematically based exploration of Southeast Asia's geographical and cultural diversity, which takes advantage of Singapore's position and character as a microcosm of this diversity. Blending classroom instruction on NUS Kent Ridge campus with hands-on fieldwork in Singapore, Cambodia, and Thailand, SEA in Context offers modules on Southeast Asia with anthropological, historical and archaeological concentrations. The core module, "SE2222: Southeast Asia In Context" provides a broad overview of Southeast Asia from a historical, sociological, and anthropological perspective. Its partner module, "SE2880A: Southeast Asia's Cultural Mosaic," will equip students with the analytical tools for the comparative study of society and culture, and features a ten-day field trip to various religious, cultural, and archaeological sites in Cambodia and Thailand. Both modules deploy context-based learning by combining in-class instruction at NUS campus with local and regional hands-on experience of Southeast Asian life. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Singapore, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Yale Credit and 1 NUS Credit. Tuition: $4,300. Program fee: $1,155. Course dates: June 16 - July 20.
title: Southeast Asia in Context
subject: ANTH

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Students will have the opportunity to study and be in class with local students from St. Xavier's University. Critical engagement with contemporary Indian politics, society, culture, and religion through an intensive and immersive study in Mumbai, one of the largest cities in the world. Topics include: urban poverty, urban town planning, housing problems, sanitation, cultural politics, religious and sectarian violence, caste politics, class ghettoization, communal violence, migration, urban-rural divide, Bollywood and popular culture. Students choose ANTH or SAST credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For more information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: May 31 - July 4.
title: Bombay: City, Society and Culture
subject: ANTH

description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non–science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Science of Modern Technology
subject: APHY

description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 25 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: APHY

description: The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to the earliest cities, states, and empires. Explores how these societies developed and why they collapsed. Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
short_title: The Genesis and Collapse of W...
title: The Genesis and Collapse of World Civilizations
subject: ARCG

description: An introduction to drawing, emphasizing pictorial syntax and the articulation of space. Class work is based on observational study. Assigned projects address fundamental technical and conceptual problems suggested by historical and recent artistic practice. No prior drawing experience necessary. Enrollment limited to 20 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,650. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Basic Drawing
subject: ART

description: An introduction to basic painting issues, stressing a beginning command of the conventions of pictorial space and the language of color. Class assignments and individual projects explore technical, conceptual, and historical issues central to the language of painting. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,650. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Painting Basics
subject: ART

description: Exploration of the transition of photographic processes and techniques into digital formats. A range of tools are presented including scanning, digital cameras, retouching, color correction, basic composition, and inkjet printing. Students produce original work throughout the technical component of the class. After mastering the basics, students work toward the completion of a final project, and the focus of the remaining classes is on critiques. Throughout the term, lectures and presentations raise critical issues concerning the impact of digital applications and by-products on the medium of photography. Students must have access to a digital camera and bring it to class. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,650. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Introduction to Digital Photography
subject: ART

description: A studio introduction to typographic communication on the Internet. Students will conceive, design, and build a website with a content management system. The relationship between web server, web browser, content author, graphic designer, and user will be emphasized as both technical issues and aesthetic opportunities. Sustainability and evolution of a website over time is emphasized. HTML, CSS, image preparation, and basics of PHP will be taught utilizing the computer facilities at the Yale School of Art. No previous knowledge necessary. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,650. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Introduction to Interactive Design: WWW
subject: ART

description: Introduction to the principles, history, and practice of animation in visual art and film. With a primary focus on production, this course utilizes historical and theoretical developments in twentieth- and twenty-first-century animation as a framework for making digital animation. Production focuses primarily on digital stop-animation and compositing, as well as 2D and 3D computer-generated animation. Students gain an understanding of the principles of animation and develop fundamental skill-sets in Apple Final Cut Pro, Adobe After Effects, and Autodesk Maya 2012. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,650. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Principles of Animation
subject: ART

description: A nontechnical introduction to stellar populations and the structure and evolution of the Milky Way galaxy; external galaxies, radio galaxies, and quasars; cosmology and the expanding universe. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Galaxies and the Universe
subject: ASTR

description: Offered in Santiago, Chile. This six-week course will be held at the University of Chile as part of the Yale-University of Chile collaboration in astronomy and astrophysics education and research. The course is an introduction to astrophysics and to ground-based observing techniques. Extensive observing using research facilities at the Cerro Calan and Cerro Tololo Observatories. Field trips to other major Andean observatories. Students will be able to view the sky through premier telescopes at the clearest observational site in the Southern Hemisphere. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Santiago, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: A solid background in high school physics and mathematics is strongly recommended. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Course Dates: June 1 - July 12.
title: Introduction to Observational Astronomy
subject: ASTR

description: Introduction to the study of life at the molecular level and to cell biology and membrane physiology. Topics include the three-dimensional structures and function of large biological molecules, the human genome, the design of antiviral drugs to treat HIV/AIDS, organization and functional properties of biological membranes, membrane physiology and signaling, rough endoplasmic reticulum and synthesis of membrane/secretory membrane proteins, endocytosis, the cytoskeleton, and cell division. Covers the material of BIOL 101 and 102, the first half of the yearlong introductory biology sequence. Followed in the summer by BIOL S106. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Biochemistry, Biophysics, and Cell Biology
subject: BIOL

description: Introduction to genes, genetics, developmental biology, ecology, evolutionary biology, animal behavior, and the history of life. How genes control development and disease; Mendel's rules; examples of organ physiology; evolutionary transitions and natural selection; adaptation at genic, chromosomal, cellular, organismal, and supra-organismal levels; distributional and social consequences of particular suites of organismal adaptations. Covers the material of BIOL 103 and 104, the second half of the yearlong introductory biology sequence. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and 102 or BIOL S105. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Genes, Ecology, and Evolutionary Biology
subject: BIOL

description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides a comprehensive introduction to the use of statistics in the fields of epidemiology, public health, and clinical research. Students gain experience conducting and interpreting a broad range of statistical analyses. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability distributions, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, sampling, analysis of variance, nonparametric tests, and linear regression. Through weekly computer laboratory sessions, students become familiar with the SAS statistical software package.
For students in the Advanced Professional M.P.H. program; not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.
title: Accelerated Biostatistics
subject: BIS

description: A selection of Victorian texts offering a broad view of period life and culture. Emphasis on novels that show "outsiders" adjusting to the complexities of urban and rural life in nineteenth-century England. Study of the orphan, alien, disoriented, or alienated characters who find a place in society through art, intellectual enterprise, or spiritual enlightenment.
title: Victorian Fiction
subject: BRST

description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides students with an introduction to social and behavioral science issues that influence patterns of health and health care delivery. The focus is on the integration of biomedical, social, psychological, and behavioral factors that must be taken into consideration when public health initiatives are developed and implemented. This course emphasizes the integration of research from the social and behavioral sciences with epidemiology and biomedical sciences.
Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.
title: Accelerated Social and Behavioral Foundations of Health
subject: CDE

description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides a comprehensive overview of epidemiologic concepts and methods. Topics include measurements of disease frequency and association, study design (including randomized and non-randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, and ecologic studies), screening principles, reliability and validity, bias, confounding, and effect modification. After completing this course, students are able to calculate and interpret epidemiologic parameters, identify the strengths and weaknesses of various study designs, and apply the principles and methods of epidemiology to the design and analysis of new studies.
Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.
title: Accelerated Epidemiology
subject: CDE

description: Designed to introduce practical tools for directing, this course applies to anyone who is interested in working on technique as a director, whether as a career, for teachers directing a school play or for community theater productions. Topics include dramaturgy, script analysis, the director's work with the script, working with the actor, voice and speech techniques, and stage management organization. No formal training in directing necessary. Applicants should send a brief statement describing their background and areas of interest. A transcript is not required. Limited housing is available for this course; contact Yale Summer Session at 203.432.2430 for details. CEU Credit. Tuition $600. This intense course requires a full commitment of the student's time. Students must be available from 9:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday through Friday as well as Saturday afternoons and evenings and Sunday morning and afternoon. The faculty reserves the right to add, extend, or adjust scheduled hours to accommodate the progress of the class. Upon successful completion of this course, Connecticut Continuing Education Units will be awarded. Course not open to pre-college students. Dates: July 18 - 27.
title: A Practical Approach to Directing I
subject: CEU

description: Multidisciplinary approach to studying the nature of the mind. How the fields of philosophy, psychology, neuroscience, computer science, and linguistics contribute methods, theories, and research to addressing questions about the workings of the mind. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Introduction to Cognitive Science
subject: CGSC

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscinece, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Audit $345. Technology fee $85. Offered in both Session A: June 2 - July 4 and Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
subject: CGSC

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscinece, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. title: Moralities of Everyday Life
subject: CGSC

description: The study of language from the perspective of cognitive science. Exploration of the mental structures that underlie our ability to learn and process language, drawing on studies of normal and atypical language development and processing, brain imaging, neuropsychology, and computational modeling. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Cognitive Science of Language
subject: CGSC

description: Offered Online. Interdisciplinary exploration of the cognitive, social, and emotional capacities of creatures lacking language and culture. The extent to which our complex psychology is unique to mature humans; the relative richness of a mental life without language or culture. Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. Enrollment limited. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee $85. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
short_title: Mental Lives of Babies and An...
title: Mental Lives of Babies and Animals
subject: CGSC

description: Basic concepts necessary to understand how chemistry affects life in the modern world. Laws, events, and other ways that chemistry shapes human lives. Intended for non–science majors; no prerequisites. Does not satisfy premedical chemistry requirements or requirements for the Chemistry major. Not open to students who have completed another chemistry course at Yale. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Chemistry in the Modern World
subject: CHEM

description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Session A: stoichiometry, atomic structure, chemical bonding, molecular structure, gas laws, properties of solutions. These lecture courses (CHEM S114/S115), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. They do not, however, include a laboratory component. The laboratory is an additional requirement for medical school that is not satisfied by these courses, and chemistry laboratory courses are not offered in Summer Session in 2014. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: ComprehensiveGeneralChemistry
subject: CHEM

description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Session B: chemical kinetics and thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, acid-base theory, electrochemistry, transition metal chemistry, introduction to organic chemistry. These lecture courses (CHEM S114/S115), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. They do not, however, include a laboratory component. The laboratory is an additional requirement for medical school that is not satisfied by these courses, and chemistry laboratory courses are not offered in Summer Session in 2014. Prerequisite: CHEM 114 or the equivalent in advanced placement. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Comprehensive General Chemistry
subject: CHEM

description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session A: structure and bonding, chemical energetics, stereochemistry, alkanes, nucleophilic substitution, infrared spectroscopy, alkenes and alkynes, alcohols and ethers. These lecture courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. They do not, however, include a laboratory component. For college students and beyond. After college level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Organic Chemistry
subject: CHEM

description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session B: aldehydes and ketones, strategies in organic synthesis, carboxylic acid derivatives, carbonyl condensation reactions, sulfur and phosphorus compounds, bifunctional molecules, carbohydrates, organic nitrogen compounds, amino acids and proteins. These lecture courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. They do not, however, include a laboratory component. The laboratory is an additional requirement for medical school that is not satisfied by these courses, and chemistry laboratory courses are not offered in Summer Session in 2014. For college students and beyond. After college-level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Organic Chemistry
subject: CHEM

description: Offered Online. Survey of current understandings and treatment of autism from infancy through adulthood. Topics include etiology, diagnosis and assessment, treatment and advocacy, and social neuroscience methods. Focus on ways in which research findings are integrated into diagnosis and treatment practices. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Autism and Related Disorders
subject: CHLD

description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Classical Mythologies
subject: CLCV

description: Exploration of imagery of myths on Greek works of art and architecture ranging from great temples such as the Parthenon to small objects such as painted pots. Course includes visits to Yale's collection. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
short_title: Art and Myth in Ancient Greece
title: Art and Myth in Ancient Greece
subject: CLCV

description: An exploration of the myriad ways in which law and technology intersect, with a special focus on broadband, the Internet, and how telecommunications law has evolved to where it is today. Topics include the breakup of the Bell system monopoly, Wi-Fi, FCC regulation of broadband and the Internet, voice-over Internet protocol, smartphones, and mobile networks. No previous experience with computers or law necessary. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Issues Internet&Telecomms Law
subject: CPSC

description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, language, and film-making practicum (with guest lectures by prominent economic and cultural leaders). Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. Includes a four-day film-making practicum: under the supervision of cinematographers Gary Griffin, Josef Lustig, and Alice Arnold, students shoot two or three short films based on their screenplays written in class. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students performing exceptionally in Czech language may qualify for placement above L1 during the 2014-15 academic year. Students choose FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: July 4 - August 10.
title: In Prague Film and Fiction
subject: CZEC

description: Exploration and development of the fundamentals of the actor's craft based on the principles of Stanislavski. The course is actually a concise training program in which each student takes more than one class. The classes are in the following areas: (1) play analysis class, to understand what is to be acted; (2) acting class, to learn the application of basic acting techniques; (3) vocal production class, to improve vocal and articulation skills; (4) improvisation and mask class, to help free the imagination and to build confidence in spontaneous self-expression; (5) movement class, to strengthen the body and to encourage the use of the body for emotional expression; and (6) scene study class, to understand how the classes listed above come together when working on a scene. The instructors constitute a teaching staff of working professionals and are assisted by teaching associates giving the students individual attention. The summer drama program requires a full commitment of the student's time. Classes are held in the mornings, afternoons, and two evenings each week, Monday through Friday, with 26 to 28 classroom hours each week, 4 to 6 library hours each week, plus additional hours for individual tutorials and scheduled rehearsal time. Extra evening and Saturday morning sessions may be scheduled for group activities and additional classes. A single grade will be awarded for the course. Enrollment is limited. Complete applications must include a resume of relevant experience and a letter of recommendation from a drama teacher or other theater professional. Application deadline: May 1. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Yale Summer Conservatory for Actors
subject: DRMA

description: Offered in Uganda. Introduction to research and fieldwork in tropical ecology and conservation; taught by a mix of international faculty and local experts. Including lectures and seminars, the course is centered on the fieldwork that illustrates how current concepts are being approached and modern techniques are used in research. Working collaborative teams, student design and undertake their own research project. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Uganda, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 27 - July 27.
title: Tropical Field Ecology
subject: E&EB

description: The structure and function of the human body, organization of body systems, and the study of regional anatomy. Modern body imaging methods. Fundamental dissection methods. Students will perform a complete dissection of a human cadaver. Meets departmental requirements for the major and is appropriate for students seeking to fulfill health profession prerequisites. Prerequisite: BIOL 101, 102, 103, and 104 or an equivalent full-year introduction to biology sequence. For college students and beyond. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Lab fee $600. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Human Anatomy
subject: E&EB

description: Study of aquatic habitats of the U.S. central highlands (Appalachians, Ozark, and Quachita Mountains). The taxonomic diversity, ecology, biogeography, and evolutionary biology of aquatic animals, such as insects, crayfishes, mussels, and fishes. Includes a two-week field trip to observe and sample riverine habitats in Virginia, Kentucky, Tennessee, and Georgia. Prerequisite: BIOL 104 or equivalent. Recommended preparation: E&EB 225. 2 Credits. Tuition 6,700. Course fee: $300. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Conservation & Biodiversity of Aquatic Habitats
subject: E&EB

description: Offered in Tokyo, Japan. This course surveys the cultural history of Tokyo through literature, film, art, anime, and architecture and living spaces. Starting with the heyday of Edo when the city lent its name not only to the shogun's capital, already a thriving urban center of over a million inhabitants, but to the historical period itself (1604-1868), we will examine the city's reincarnation as the imperial metropolis of Tokyo in the Meiji period (1868-1912), the phoenix-like cycles of destruction and reconstruction through the Great Kanto Earthquake (1923), the firebombing of the city during WWII, and other significant changes in the topography and lived experiences of the city. Particular emphasis will be given to contextualizing the classroom content with field trips to museums, historic neighborhoods, and a hands-on experience of living in Tokyo. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Japan, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For more information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: May 31 - July 5.
title: Humanities of Tokyo
subject: EALL

description: Introduction to the principles of microeconomics, supply and demand, consumer theory, and competitive markets. Applications to contemporary policy issues such as rent control, minimum wage, antitrust policy, pollution, and income inequality. For college students and beyond. May not be taken after ECON 108 or 110. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Introduction to Microeconomics
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Introduction to the principles of microeconomics, supply and demand, consumer theory, and competitive markets. Applications to contemporary policy issues such as rent control, minimum wage, antitrust policy, pollution, and income inequality. For college students and beyond. May not be taken after ECON 108 or 110. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: IntroductiontoMicroeconomics
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to basic macroeconomic concepts and theories, such as national income accounting, theories of growth, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policy, banking, finance, and economic crises, with special emphasis on the recent financial crisis. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, 115 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Methods of evaluation of quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After introductory microeconomics and MATH 112 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30181) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRN: 30182).
title: Econometrics and Data Analysis I
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Methods of evaluation of quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After introductory microeconomics and MATH 112 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30181) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRN: 30182).
title: Econometrics and Data Analysis I
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to the theory of multiperson decision problems and its application in economic analysis. Discussion of static and dynamic noncooperative games with particular attention to the notions of Nash equilibrium and sub-game perfect equilibrium. Prerequisite: two terms of introductory economics (ECON 115 and 116 or the equivalent). For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Game Theory
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. An introduction to the theory of multiperson decision problems and its application in economic analysis. Discussion of static and dynamic noncooperative games with particular attention to the notions of Nash equilibrium and sub-game perfect equilibrium. Prerequisite: two terms of introductory economics (ECON 115 and 116 or the equivalent). For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Game Theory
subject: ECON

description: Application of economic principles to the study of the U.S. health care system. Emphasis on basic principles about the structure of the U.S. system, current problems, proposed solutions, and the context of health policy making and politics. Prerequisite: a course on introductory microeconomics. May not be taken after ECON 467. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4
title: Health Economics and Public Policy
subject: ECON

description: Offered in Beijing, China. This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities Global Summer Program. For students from IARU/GSP universities only. An overview of the Chinese economy, with attention to its rapid growth in the past two decades and its current challenges. The cultural and political background of the economy, China's market transition, manufacturing and financial sectors, foreign trade, foreign direct investment and technology transfer, and the reform of state-owned enterprises. Prerequisite: introductory economics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Beijing, costs of room and board in Beijing, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Course dates: June 30 - July 25.
title: Introduction to the Chinese Economy
subject: ECON

description: The role of government in the economy and in our economic lives. Reasons for government intervention in the market economy and the impact of government expenditure programs and taxation systems on welfare and behavior. Tools of microeconomics applied to issues such as government response to global warming, the impact of redistribution and social insurance on individual behavior, school choice, social security vs. private retirement savings accounts, and government vs. private health insurance. Prerequisite: introductory microeconomics. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Public Economics
subject: ECON

description: Offered in Paris, France. Parties engaging in economic exchange often organize their relationships through contracts and other private legal structures. In this course we will study the organization of exchange and the body of law and private institutions that govern and influence its structure. The course curriculum develops through a substantive theoretical component and a practical component, with on-site modules at the International Court of Commercial Arbitration in Paris. A comparative legal and institutional approach will be maintained throughout. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: MATH 112, ECON 121, or permission of instructor. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition: $6,700. Course Dates: June 14 - July 19.
title: PrivateLaw&Order inUS&France
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Corruption, a manifestation of the principal-agent problem, is an obstacle to economic efficiency. This course examines the economic, cultural, and political causes and consequences of corruption; cross-country comparisons of corruption levels; and examples of successful reforms and policies to combat corruption in bureaucracy and business. Students will complete a documented research project as part of the course. Prerequisite: ECON 108a or b, 110a, or 115a or b, or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Causes&ConsequencesCorruption
subject: ECON

description: This is a course on efficiency; the First and Second Welfare Theorems, in simple general equilibrium models of competitive markets and market failures; and where the welfare theorems do not hold, that is, externalities, public goods, and monopoly pricing. In particular, we consider and compare the relative merits of the Kaldor-Hicks compensation principle in partial equilibrium analysis and the Pareto principle in general equilibrium analysis. Prerequisites: ECON 121 and MATH 112. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Welfare Economics and Equality
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. This is a course on efficiency; the First and Second Welfare Theorems, in simple general equilibrium models of competitive markets and market failures; and where the welfare theorems do not hold, that is, externalities, public goods, and monopoly pricing. In particular, we consider and compare the relative merits of the Kaldor-Hicks compensation principle in partial equilibrium analysis and the Pareto principle in general equilibrium analysis. Prerequisites: ECON 121 and MATH 112. Enrollment limited. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Welfare Economics and Equality
subject: ECON

description: This is an intensive summer seminar in Latin American Development Problems and Policies. The course uses economic theory and quantitative analysis, political economy viewpoints, and institutional and governance approaches to analyze development problems of contemporary Latin American economies. Two broad topics include macroeconomics and stabilization, and economic reform and liberalization. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A (June 2 - July 4).
title: Development Problems and Policies in Latin America
subject: ECON

description: Recent developments in international economics. Trade policy and market structure; the economics of trading blocs such as the EU and NAFTA; the economic consequences of continued U.S. external deficits; globalization and inequality; exchange rates, interest rates, and volatility; speculative capital flows and exchange rate policies; and financial crises and the prospects for the European Monetary Union. Prerequisites: intermediate microeconomics and macroeconomics or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Topics in International Economics
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to information transmission and storage and their impact on society. Technological issues and trade-offs that affect the design of digital systems. Smartphone sensors and actuators; signal processing and design for data transmission; information transmission on the World Wide Web. Projects include analysis and design using Matlab or Excel. Intended for students in the humanities and social sciences and for freshmen considering a major in electrical engineering. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: The Digital Information Age
subject: EENG

description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Science of Modern Technology
subject: ENAS

description: Quantitative reasoning applied to evaluation of physical formulas and to interpretation of actual data. Concepts illustrated with models that simulate random data. Statistical measures predict accuracy of analytic results. Analysis ranges from paper-and-pencil and scientific calculator to Excel spreadsheets. Case studies include societal problems involving technological issues, life expectancy, and predicting Olympic gold medal performance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Data Analysis and Forecasting
subject: ENAS

description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 25 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: ENAS

description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 12. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Offered in both Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30040) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRNs 30038 or 30039).
title: Writing Seminars I
subject: ENGL

description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 12. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Offered in both Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30040) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRNs 30038 or 30039).
title: Writing Seminars I
subject: ENGL

description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 12. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Offered in both Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30040) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRNs 30038 or 30039).
title: Writing Seminars I
subject: ENGL

description: Close study of selected works of nonfiction prepares students to become critical readers and to apply professional strategies to their own writing. Readings from such authors as Joan Didion, Malcolm Gladwell, Maxine Hong Kingston, N. Scott Momaday, George Orwell, Brent Staples, Jonathan Swift, Henry David Thoreau, Tom Wolfe, and Alice Walker. Written assignments, involving frequent revision, include autobiography, portraiture, nature writing, cultural critique, and formal argument. It is recommended that students who have not completed an introductory college-level writing course take ENGL S114 instead. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Reading and Writing the Modern Essay
subject: ENGL

description: An introduction to the diversity and the continuity of the English language tradition through close reading of four poets from the fourteenth through the seventeenth centuries, Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, and Donne. Emphasis on developing skills of literary interpretation and critical writing. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Major English Poets
subject: ENGL

description: This course serves both as an introduction to as well as an exploration of American literature from the nineteenth century to the present. We will ask many questions of these texts, not the least of which is: what do we mean when we say "American?" Given the wide range of the body of work that comprises American literature, however, we will also periodically ask in passing what we mean by "literature" so as to consider what roles the literary plays in creating and shaping the possibilities of social imagination, private and public discourse, as well as one's own identity. Emphasis on analytical reading, critical writing, and class discussions. Authors include Melville, Poe, Hawthorne, Whitman, Dickinson, Barnes, Toomer, H. Crane, W.C. Williams, L. Hughes, and M. Robinson. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Readings in American Literature
subject: ENGL

description: Conducted as a workshop, this course offers students the opportunity to write fiction and the particular sort of nonfiction that reflects and explores the narrative of their own lives. The focus will be on elements common to all storytelling, among them, character, narrative development, voice, and clarity of language and thought. Students may concentrate on a single genre, or, if they wish, experiment with both. Readings will include selections from contemporary American fiction and creative nonfiction. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be submitted with the online application. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Introduction to Writing Fiction and Creative Nonfiction
subject: ENGL

description: A study of ten comedies and romances, their festivities and their reservations. Extensive practice in writing critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read A Midsummer Night’s Dream. (The Signet edition is preferred.) Selections from filmed productions of the plays are screened semiweekly, and students are asked to attend a number of these screenings. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Shakespeare: Comedies and Romances
subject: ENGL

description: Study of three histories and seven tragedies at the pinnacle of Shakespeare's career. Focus on the source of each play's pathos and the nature of its poetic sublimity; some attention to performance and to the relation between the genres of history and tragedy. Extensive practice in writing short and medium-length critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read Julius Caesar. (The Signet edition, ordered through The Yale Bookstore, is preferred, but the Norton genre volumes are especially handsome substitutions; the Arden single play editions are more than acceptable if their price is not intimidating.) The regular course meetings will be supplemented by six evening screenings, and students are required to attend at least five of these. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Shakespeare: Histories and Tragedies
subject: ENGL

description: Offered Online. A study of Milton's major poetry, with attention to his relation to the cultural, social, and political struggles of the Puritan Revolution. Students will watch or listen to pre-recorded lectures, and will meet online for biweekly seminar discussions. Satisfies pre-1800 requirement. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Milton
subject: ENGL

description: Offered in the Beinecke Rare Book Library. The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the hand-press book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of firsthand encounters with manuscripts, rare books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
subject: ENGL

description: Introductory writing course in nonfiction for students who wish to write history, biography, or narrative journalism. Develops the craft of turning real events, past or present, into plot- and character-driven stories that compete with the pleasures of fiction. Examines model texts of nonfiction narratives:Âtheir structure, voice, use of character, claims, and rhetorical moves. Students research, write, and revise their own nonfiction texts, set in the past or in the present, and based on archival research, interviews (where appropriate), and secondary reading. Prerequisite: a 200-level English or History course. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Writing History and Nonfiction Narrative
subject: ENGL

description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Examines travel writing, surveying a wide range of works, from long-form place essays to destination articles, from travel memoir to adventure odysseys. Readings will acquaint students with the tropes of the genre and the techniques by which writers capture the essential qualities of a place. In examining the works of writers like Paul Theroux, Ryszard Kapuscinski, Jan Morris, and Pico Iyer, we will be paying close attention to how voyages lend travel writers structure: a natural beginning, middle, and end. Students are encouraged to take advantage of their geographic mobility for their assignments and tasked to find an innovative mode or vehicle of exploring their chosen place. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: July 18 - August 15.
title: Travel Writing
subject: ENGL

description: Offered Online. Twentieth-century American drama and theater. Modernist innovations of Eugene O'Neill and the Provincetown Players, the socially committed drama of the Depression-era Group Theater and the Federal Theater Project, the rise of musical theater, Thornton Wilder's metatheatricality, Tennessee Williams's staging of sexual ambivalence, and Arthur Miller's parables of American ambition. Readings in contemporary drama by Edward Albee, David Mamet, Sam Shepard, Maria Irene Fornes, and Suzan-Lori Parks. Discussion of changing acting approaches and a survey of experimental theater. When possible, readings will be supplemented with viewings of performances on video. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Modern American Drama
subject: ENGL

description: Study of drama, performance, and dance-theater created in the last ten years, with special attention to works produced in 2013 and 2014. Readings from both published and unpublished American and British plays, contemporary criticism, interviews, and essays by the artists themselves. Video of works created by companies such as Elevator Repair Service, Les Freres Corbusier, and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Will include attendance of productions in and around New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Theater Now
subject: ENGL

description: An examination of creative and analytic responses to the changes in daily life brought about by the rapid proliferation of digital media and forms of communication. Both utopian and dystopian visions of digital society will be considered. Works to include nonfiction by Marshall McLuhan, Jaron Lanier, Clay Shirky, and Evgeny Morozov; fiction by Russell Hoban and Dave Eggers; and films such as 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Social Network, The Internship, and Her. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Digital Life, Fiction and Nonfiction
subject: ENGL

description: Techniques of in-depth reporting, ranging from interviews and document research to journalistic storytelling; the evolution of "muckraking" in the United States; and the ethical, philosophical, and political issues raised by such work. Improvement of the students' practical research and narrative skills through weekly assignments and a term-long writing project. Designed equally for those with journalistic experience and for those with skills in other arenas. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Investigative Journalism
subject: ENGL

description: An advanced workshop for writers who want to review the performing arts for newspapers, magazines, and other media. Weekly assignments to review screenings and performances, many of which will be part of New Haven's International Festival of Arts and Ideas. Class trip to New York City to review a theater production. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Reviewing Film, Theater, Music, and Dance
subject: ENGL

description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Lies and Deception
subject: EP&E

description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Environmental Ethics
subject: EP&E

description: Causes of ethnic conflict and its most violent forms, including ethnic civil war. Critically reviews the dominant explanations of ethnic conflict and applies them to actual cases, including current examples of ethnic war, to arrive at an in-depth understanding of the problem and consider some of its solutions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Ethnic Conflict
subject: EP&E

description: The Internship is a degree requirement that is completed in the summer between the first and second academic years. Students work with their faculty advisers and the Office of Career Services to identify suitable placements, which include medical care facilities, community agencies, research projects, laboratories, and other sites engaged in public health activities. The internship experience often serves as a basis for the M.P.H. thesis. The internship is displayed on the transcript with a grade of "S" (Satisfactory) upon completion. A course unit is not given for the summer internship. All students must complete a Summer Internship with the exception of those in the Advanced Professional M.P.H. Program. The Summer Internship may be used to complete the Public Health Practice requirement with prior approval from the Office of Community Health.
title: Summer Internship
subject: EPH

description:
The thesis (2 course units) is typically a yearlong project that is completed in the second academic year and is the culmination of the student's educational experience at YSPH. It is frequently a report of a small research project performed independently by the student. Students work with faculty advisers in designing their project and in writing the thesis. Detailed guidelines for the thesis are outlined in Appendix II.
The thesis is not a requirement for students in the Health Care Management, Health Policy, or Advanced Professional M.P.H. programs (except for those in the Occupational and Environmental Medicine track).
title: Thesis
subject: EPH

description: Seminar that covers the technology use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: EVST

description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, language, and film-making practicum (with guest lectures by prominent economic and cultural leaders). Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar(Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. Includes a four-day film-making practicum: under the supervision of cinematographers Gary Griffin, Josef Lustig and Alice Arnold, students shoot two or three short films based on their screenplays written in class. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students performing exceptionally in Czech language may qualify for placement above L1 during the 2014-15 academic year. Students choose FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: July 4 - August 10.
title: In Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Paris, France. Paris is the cultural capital of cinema. No city has been celebrated in film as frequently and as lovingly as Paris. This course is an introduction to French cinema and culture from 1915 to the present which focuses on the mystery, romance, youth, and consumerism of Paris. The class will explore Parisian neighborhoods on city walks, visit two preeminent French cinema institutions (the Cinematique Francaise and the Institut Lumiere) and view films together. These films will include Breathless, La Haine, and Amelie. All readings will be in English with further optional readings in French. All films are subtitled in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Course dates: July 5 - August 9.
title: Paris and the Cinema
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Room with a View, Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, Sandra, Mar nero, Good Morning Babylon, Fiorile, and the Florentine episode of Paisa. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 22 - July 27.
title: Italian Language and Cinema in Tuscany
subject: FILM

description: Overview of the evolution of computer animation in the American context and across related visual media (animated films, live-action cinema, and video games). Covers the historical, aesthetic, and technological developments in the field of computer-generated imagery over the past quarter century, placing emphasis on situating digital animation within larger debates in Film and Media Studies. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Computer Animation: Art, Industry, Society
subject: FILM

description: A survey of the histories of both the Hollywood novel and films about Hollywood. Examination of the ways in which these two genres portray "the dream factory"—its past, its present, and its future—as well as the way they interact. Books include Harry Leon Wilson's Merton at the Movies, Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and I Should Have Stayed Home, F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star, and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
short_title: The Hollywood Novel and the H...
title: The Hollywood Novel and the Hollywood Movie
subject: FILM

description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
subject: FILM

description: A study of the interrelations among popular sport, cinema, television, radio, print, and social media. Explores topics of identity, commerce, and civics through contemporary texts (Hunger Games, Senna, Invictus), and introduces the history of sport in media culture. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Sports and Media
subject: FILM

description: In this hands-on workshop, students make fully-realized scenes and critique narrative motion pictures. This class is filmmaking by practical application--script breakdown for production preparation: producing, budgeting, scheduling, camera aesthetics and techniques, directing, working with actors, lighting, sound design, editing, and media management. Collaborative independent industry-standard procedure is applied in production to well-written scenes from critically acclaimed motion pictures. Film professionals instruct and guide students in the application of industry standards. The course is fully integrated with FILM S203 to provide filmmaking students with a pool of acting talent and enable students to move beyond the technological requirements of the medium and establish common creative communication. Students work with the latest gear, such as vari-cams, stabilization, LED lights, jibs, and post- production technology, such as pre-visualization software and Final Cut X at Yale's Digital Media Center for the Arts. Nightly screenings of narrative movies further understanding of the medium's history and the students' creative vocabulary. Beginning with seminars, readings, and workshop exercises, students progress to a fully-realized scene. This workshop requires a full daily commitment of the student's time, including five hours of classroom instruction, two hours of screenings, one to two hours of reading homework and workshop projects outside of class time and on weekends. Although no prior filmmaking is required, a visual artistic sample in any medium must be included with application. Enrollment limited to 16. For students in college or beyond only. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: IndependentFilmmakingWorkshop
subject: FILM

description: Students are on camera from day one in this intensive, full-time course that is integrated with the Independent Film Production Workshop (Film S-202). The On-Camera Workshop allows the student actor to solve the artistic and technical challenges of film acting. Students learn on-camera audition techniques and the tenets of good acting under the pressures and demands of film production. With rehearsed on-camera scene work, they acquire the technical language of cinema and practice acquired film acting techniques. Students act in one or more of the scenes produced by the Independent Film Production Workshop. Actors also audition for, and get feedback from, a Los Angeles casting director. Meeting with the casting director includes a Q & A about the business. Students are introduced to skills that deepen their understanding of the filmmaking process and help them produce their own work: directing, operating a camera and editing. With the Independent Film Production Workshop, the students view classic narrative masterpieces nightly in order to gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic context as well as to develop a common vocabulary with fellow collaborators. Screenings, readings, and rehearsals supplement practical application. Daily commitments include, but are not limited to, 3-5 hours daily of classroom instruction, 2.5 hours of nightly screenings, 1-3 hours daily reading, rehearsal and shooting sessions outside of classroom time and on weekends. A one to two minute on-camera audition must be included with application. Enrollment limited to 16. For students in college or beyond only. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: The On-Camera Workshop
subject: FILM

description: An examination of the key events and ideas that shape the modern motion picture business from financial, institutional, and historical standpoints. Topics include ways that the business has evolved in response to changes in technology, distribution, and competition; how the business dictates what ends up on screen; and relationships among studios, actors, agents, independent filmmakers, distributors, and the viewing audience. Industry practitioners discuss special topics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Money and Media: The Business of Hollywood
subject: FILM

description: Eighteen films depicting some of the varied effects of war, especially the two World Wars, on individual combantants, civilians, occupied peoples and others not engaged in military action itself. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B (July 7 - August 8).
title: The Cinema of War
subject: FILM

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include films such as The Birth of a Nation, Gold Diggers of 1933, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Swaziland. This course explores the intersection of global health and visual media and focuses on global health issues such as HIV, TB, human rights, and violence in public health. Students learn filmmaking as a means for translating complex public health concepts into a format approachable by a general audience. In addition to traditional learning, students work with instructors, guest lecturers, and production personnel to create a short film on a selected global health topic. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Swaziland, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: May 31 - July 5.
title: Visual Approaches to Global Health
subject: FILM

description: A seminar and workshop in screenplay writing. Students learn the basics of the craft by reading existing scripts, looking at films from a writer's perspective, and writing a short screenplay. Additional hours of individual screenings required. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Screenwriting
subject: FILM

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French. This course focuses on developing all language skills, communicative proficiency, self-expression, and cultural insights through extensive use of authentic audio, video material, and field trips. Conducted entirely in unsimplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work, and all field trips are required. Priority is given to Yale students. description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings; discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals; films; songs; stories; and clips from French television. description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent; and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit.
