title: Belle Époque France
subject: FREN

description: This six-week course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities Global Summer Program. Two students from each partner university, including two from Yale, will be admitted to this course. Partial funding is provided for all students enrolled. The course will cover the mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and of the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 29 - August 8.
title: Foreign Policy and International Law
subject: GLBL

description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
subject: GLBL

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Credit only on completion of GMAN S140. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. description: Political, cultural, and ideological background of the Holocaust and its representation in film, art and literature. Relationship of Nazi thought to culture, science, and technology. Readings and discussion in English. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: The Holocaust: Rhetoric, Film, and Politics

description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: The Logic of Dreams
subject: GMST

description: Introduction to ancient Greek. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for GREK S120. No prior knowledge of Greek assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Beginning Greek: The Elements of Grammar

title: The Elements of Greek Grammar
subject: GREK

description: The history of westward expansion and of the places west of the Mississippi River, as told through the people who saw it, experienced it, and made it happen. Beginning in the colonial era and concluding in the present day, with an emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries and international comparisons. Research will include the use of materials held at the Beinecke Rare Book Library. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

description: Introductory writing course in nonfiction for students who wish to write history, biography, or narrative journalism. Develops the craft of turning real events, past or present, into plot- and character-driven stories that compete with the pleasures of fiction. Examines model texts of nonfiction narratives:ÃÂtheir structure, voice, use of character, claims, and rhetorical moves. Students research, write, and revise their own nonfiction texts, set in the past or in the present, and based on archival research, interviews (where appropriate), and secondary reading. Prerequisite: a 200-level English or History course. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Writing History and Nonfiction Narrative
subject: HIST

description: Medieval Europe studied through an investigation of the Crusades movement with views of Western European, Byzantine, and Muslim participants. The significance of the Crusades to Western Europe, the Byzantine Empire, and the Muslim Near East from politcial, economic, religious, and cultural perspectives. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Crusades and Medieval Europe
subject: HIST

description: Focus on Viking raids, emigration from Scandinavia (to Normandy, Newfoundland, and the Danelaw, among other places), Viking ship technology, the creation of Scandinavian kingdoms, trade, life at home in Scandinavia, religion, and art and literature. 1 Credit. title: History of the Vikings
subject: HIST

description: Offered in the Beinecke Rare Book Library. The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the hand-press book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of firsthand encounters with manuscripts, rare books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
subject: HIST

description: Course description will be available soon.

description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: The Cold War
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,350. Course dates: June 29 - August 2.
title: History of Southeastern Europe

description: Survey of the history of China, Japan, and Korea from the seventh century to the present. Focus on two separate empires: the Tang and Japanese. Attention to interactions among East Asian regions in the past and today. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Empires of East Asia
subject: HIST

description: Although the global city is often considered a recent development, this course examines the long history of connections between the local space of American cities and larger global forces since the nineteenth century. We will explore how immigration, international commerce and exchange, tourism, real estate, and cultural spaces like museums and parks have made U.S. cities profoundly global spaces and how cities have been central to the history of the United States as a global power. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

description: Explores the intersection of modern art and political upheaval during the last two centuries in the Modern Middle East. Spans from Napoleon's invasion of Egypt in 1798, tracing a trajectory of fine arts and visual culture in the region, to the graffiti, cartoons, and social media of the Arab Spring. Focuses on questions of the impact of political change on art and visual culture; the role of ethnicity, gender, and class in modern Middle Eastern art; and the lasting mark of colonialism, post-colonialism, and neo-colonialism on the region. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

description: The historical relationship between art and science in the West, from the Renaissance to the present. Case studies illustrate the similarities and differences between the way artists and scientists each model the world, in the studio and the laboratory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HUMS

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Room with a View, Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, Sandra, Mar nero, Good Morning Babylon, Fiorile, and the Florentine episode of Paisa. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students from liberal arts and fine arts backgrounds with or without prior experience. Studio Practice is an intensive study of painting and drawing focusing on the dynamics of the artist's studio practice of developing and constructing work. It is crafted for those who wish to study and experience the intimate process of personal idea imaging through the language of painting and drawing. Of great importance to the course is the development of strategies necessary for individual discovery, observation/analysis,and relational thinking. The residential program demands commitment, a strong work ethic and study within a 24/7 curriculum. All applicants should consult Robert Reed prior to completing the online application. Enrollment is limited to 15 participants. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a one- or two-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Independent Research in the Sciences
subject: IDRS

description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a one- or two-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Independent Research in the Sciences
subject: IDRS

description: Eight weeks in Grado (CRN: 30135), or three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena (CRN: 30134). An intensive course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students will be able to choose a preference in the application of the Siena or Grado programs, but will be assigned to either as necessary because of seats available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Grado, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120 (in Grado CRN: 30138, in Siena CRN: 30137). Credit only on completion of ITAL S120. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: May 31 - July 26.

subject: ITAL

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Room with a View, Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, Sandra, Mar nero, Good Morning Babylon, Fiorile, and the Florentine episode of Paisà. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: June 21 - July 26.
title: Italian Language and Cinema in Tuscany
subject: ITAL

An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Open to Yale students only. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL 140. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent. Credit only on completion of ITAL S140. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 11/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.

subject: ITAL

subject: ITAL

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. A critical reading, in Italian, of Dante's Divina Commedia, and the Vita nova. This course will place the two works in the moral, political, artistic and intellectual context of the City of Florence at the end of the thirteenth century by relating these major texts to parallel concerns Dante shared with other Florentine artist, intellectuals, and poets. Prerequisite: Open to students who passed ITAL 140 or 145 (L4) or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 21 - July 26.
title: Dante and Tuscany
subject: ITAL

description: Introduction to Latin. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for LATN 120. No prior knowledge of Latin assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Beginning Latin: The Elements of Grammar
subject: LATN

description: Continuation of LATN 110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Latin authors. The sequence LATN 110, 120 prepares for 131 or 141. Prerequisite: LATN 110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Beginning Latin: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
subject: LATN

description: Readings in Latin of approximately two books of Virgil's Aeneid with an introduction to Virgilian grammar, vocabulary, and context. Prerequisite: completion of an introductory course in Latin (LATN 110 and 120). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Latin Poetry: An Introduction
subject: LATN

description: A survey of language and linguistic variation in the Americas from prehistoric times to contemporary society. Native American languages; European colonial languages; contact languages; North American English dialects; social, ethnic, and gender variation in speech. Introduction to concepts in language contact and change, language geography, dialectology, and sociolinguistics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Language in America
subject: LING

description: The study of language from the perspective of cognitive science. Exploration of the mental structures that underlie our ability to learn and process language, drawing on studies of normal and atypical language development and processing, brain imaging, neuropsychology, and computational modeling. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Cognitive Science of Language
subject: LING

description: Cultural, historical, and linguistic aspects of the Hebrew and Jewish languages. How Yiddish and other Jewish languages emerged. Introduction to a multitude of linguistic technologies to include the historical-comparative method and the family tree model. Some knowledge of linguistics and/or Hebrew would be helpful, but not necessary. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: History of Hebrew & Jewish Languages
subject: LING

description: Examination of how stories are told in both literary and nonliterary texts, with special attention to the act of decoding and interpreting a narrative. Emphasis on fictional form, the mechanics of plot, and questions of time and character. Topics include confession, memory, language, the representation of the self, the interplay of form and content, and the relationship between fiction and history. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Introduction to Narrative
subject: LITR

description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Classical Mythologies
subject: LITR

description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent; and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: July 5 - August 9.
title: Age of Cathedrals
subject: LITR

description: Political, cultural, and ideological background of the Holocaust and its representation in film, art and literature. Relationship of Nazi thought to culture, science, and technology. Aesthetics as the backbone and public face of the Holocaust. Will consider Kant, Nietzsche, Wagner, Heidegger, Kafka, Riefenstahl, Celan, Levi, Hersonski, Lanzmann, Quentin Tarantino. Readings and discussion in English. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: The Holocaust: Rhetoric, Film, and Politics
subject: LITR

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: May 31 - July 5
title: Belle Époque France
subject: LITR

description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: The Logic of Dreams
subject: LITR

description: How short fictions condense meaning into concise and precise structure of plot and character. How stories establish a spatial and temporal environment for characters and why readers make judgments about charcters by their actions. Point of view and subjects such as the Gothic psyche and gendered narratives will be discussed. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Short Narrative Fiction
subject: LITR

description: Limits, continuity, differentiation of elementary and transcendental functions, applications. No prior acquaintance with calculus is assumed. Pre-college students should enroll in this course only if they have a strong foundation in algebra and pre-calculus. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: CalcOfFunctionsOfeVariable I
subject: MATH

description: A continuation of MATH 112. The definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, polar coordinates, Taylor series, applications. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II
subject: MATH

description: Calculus of functions of several variables, with some linear algebra. Intended for students in the social sciences, especially those majoring in Economics. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). Yale students may not take this course after MATH 120 or 222. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
subject: MATH

description: Analytic geometry in three dimensions, using vectors. Real-valued functions of two and three variables, partial derivatives, gradient and directional derivatives, level curves and surfaces, maxima and minima. Parametrized curves in space, motion in space, line integrals; applications. After MATH 115 or with permission of instructor. May not be taken after MATH 121. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables
subject: MATH

description: Introductory survey of multidisciplinary approaches to studying the neurobiology of memory. Current conception of memory mechanisms and contributions of the fields of molecular and cell biology, psychology, neuroscience, genetics, and physics will be discussed. Some previous coursework in Biology is required. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Neurobiology of Memory
subject: MCDB

description: Experimental techniques and procedures in molecular and cell biology. Must be taken after BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or after BIOL S105. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,725. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Laboratory for Principles of Molecular, Cell, and Developmental Biology
subject: MCDB

description: A comprehensive course in cell and molecular biology.  Emphasis on general principles of cell function and rationale and design of pertinent biomedical experiments. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or BIOL S105, or permission of the instructor. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Cell Biology
subject: MCDB

description: Historical survey of the key points of contact, exchange, and contention between Islam and the Christian West from the early medieval to the modern period. Students will gain a historical understanding of the dynamics that inform the relationship between the Islamic world and Western civilization in the present time. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Islam and the West
subject: MMES

description: Explores the intersection of modern art and political upheaval during the last two centuries in the Modern Middle East. Spans from Napoleon's invasion of Egypt in 1798, tracing a trajectory of fine arts and visual culture in the region, to the graffiti, cartoons, and social media of the Arab Spring. Focuses on questions of the impact of political change on art and visual culture; the role of ethnicity, gender, and class in modern Middle Eastern art; and the lasting mark of colonialism, post-colonialism, and neo-colonialism on the region. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
short_title: Art and Revolution in the Mod...
title: Art and Revolution in the Modern Middle East
subject: MMES

description: Offered Online. MUS 558E, Introduction to the Analysis of Nontonal Music4 credits. NP. Group B. This course consists of the examination of various analytic techniques and their use in the analysis of music by Krenek, Dallapiccola, Lutoslawski, Stravinsky, Webern, and Whittenberg. Helpful, but not a prerequisite, is some prior exposure to Schenker analysis and a knowledge of the fundamentals of set theory. Session: June 16-July 18.
title: Introduction to the Analysis of Nontonal Music
subject: MUS

description: Offered Online. Do you like the sound of classical music but have always been mystified, even intimidated by it? Then this experience is for you. This course will explain the elements of classical music in simple terms using engaging, fun exercises. Once the basics are in place, we explore the full panoply of classical music, from Bach to Beethoven to Bernstein, employing pop music along the way to explain the workings of the classical masterpieces. Students need not read musical notation or know anything about classical music. The only prerequisites: a willingness to hear new sounds and a desire think about what makes great music. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Listening to Classical Music
subject: MUSI

description: Offered Online. A study of the evolution of jazz, from its precursors in the music of Africa through its beginnings in New Orleans to its fusion with rock in the 1970s. Jazz's greatest artists and their styles are presented with selected music of each jazz period and a discussion of the racial and sociological factors surrounding the genre's development. While no extensive music theory background or formal instrumental experience is required, students who can read music will be best prepared to fulfill the listening and form identification assignments. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Jazz and Race in America
subject: MUSI

description: Introduction to the roles of women in ancient Egyptian, Mesopotamian, and Aegean society, as reflected in painting, sculpture, and decorative arts, as well as in the earliest known writings of women. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Women in the Ancient World
subject: NELC

description: An intensive immersion course designed to familiarize students with modern and colonia Nahuatl. Beginning-, intermediate-, and advanced-level students may apply. Formal class hours are complemented with individual practice sessions and group cultural activities. Partial scholarships are available. Details on the Yale Latin American Iberian Studies website, http://www.yale.edu/macmillan/lais/summer.html, or contact Jean Silk, jean.silk@yale.edu, for further information. Open to undergraduate and graduate students. 3 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Program dates: June 23 - August 1.
title: Intensive Nahuatl Language and Culture
subject: NHTL

description: 2 credit hours. Sessions explore the multidisciplinary theoretical foundations that are the basis for community health nursing practice across the life span. Topics include history of community health nursing and public health science; structure and function of federal, state, and local health organizations; funding mechanisms for community health care; epidemiological and biostatistical indicators of community health; methods of family and community analyses. Required for all students in the prespecialty year.
short_title: Sem in Comm Hlth Nur & PH: Co...
title: Sem in Comm Hlth Nur & PH: Comm Hlth Nursing & PH
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. This course focuses on clinical practice essential to nursing care of women, newborns, and their families throughout the childbearing cycle and the neonatal period. Clinical settings include hospital and ambulatory care. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Clinical Practice in Maternal-Newborn Nursing
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. This course presents theory essential to the provision of nursing care to childbearing families throughout the childbearing cycle, the neonatal period, and the pre- and inter-conceptional phases. Application of the nursing process as it relates to the promotion, maintenance, and restoration of health is emphasized. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Seminar in Maternal-Newborn Nursing
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. Utilizing a family-centered approach, this course provides clinical experience in identifying and assessing children's physiological and developmental needs, and planning, implementing, and evaluating a plan of nursing care to meet the needs of a particular child and his/her family in health care settings. Students have opportunities to use principles of growth and development, knowledge of the child's and family's physical and emotional responses to illness, and principles of pediatric nursing in caring for children and their families. The student gains skill and knowledge in the nursing role and an appreciation for the importance of utilizing research findings in practice and collaborating with other health professionals. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Clinical Practice in Pediatric Nursing
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. This course presents theory essential to promote health and adaptation to illness for children and their families. Emphasis is placed on growth and development, as well as pathophysiological, social, environmental, and cultural factors that influence children's and families' response to health and illness. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Seminar in Pediatric Nursing
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours per term. This course provides clinical experience in well-child care and management of common pediatric problems in a variety of primary care settings. Students provide primary health care, acute care, and beginning case management for pediatric patients in the context of their families. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of pediatric nurse practitioner students in the first year of specialization. Four and one-half hours in a clinical setting and one and one-half to two hours per week of clinical conference.
title: Primary Care of Children I
subject: NURS

description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.
title: Master's Independent Study: Sklld Birth Attndnce in Haiti
subject: NURS

description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.
title: Master's Independent Study: Clinical Practicum in ICU Nurs
subject: NURS

description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.
title: Master's Independent Study: Plant Based Health 2
subject: NURS

description:
3.2–5.8 credit hours. This clinical course builds upon the experiences gained in 556b and provides students further opportunity to develop advanced nursing skills, clinical judgment, and evidence-based patient management strategies necessary to manage common acute and chronic health care conditions. Students participate in designated weekly primary care clinical experiences arranged by faculty. In addition, students meet weekly for a one-and-one-half-hour clinical conference that is held concurrently with clinical practice. Clinical seminar discussions for family nurse practitioner students focus on family-centered care and providing care for patients across the life span. Clinical seminar discussions for all other students focus on providing patient-centered care for patients from adolescence to senescence. Clinical conference serves as a forum for students to present and discuss cases and explore issues encountered in clinical practice. Required of adult/gerontological, family, and women's health nurse practitioner students in the final year. Eight to sixteen hours of clinical practice per week (fifteen weeks), and one and one-half hours of clinical conference per week (each term).
Taken concurrently with 757a/b and, for family nurse practitioners, with 833a/b. Prerequisite (or concurrent with): 556b.
short_title: Adv Clin Prac for A/F/G&WH NPs
title: Adv Clin Prac for A/F/G&WH NPs
subject: NURS

description:
2 credit hours per term. This course provides clinical experience in advanced pediatric primary care and management, including work with complex families. The student provides health care for children over the course of the year in the Primary Care Center, Yale-New Haven Hospital, and at selected pediatric primary care sites in the community. Required of pediatric nurse practitioner students in the final year of specialization. Four and one-half hours clinical practice per week and one and one-half hours clinical conference per week.
Prerequisite: successful completion of 632a/b.
title: Primary Care of Children II
subject: NURS

description: 1.7 credit hours. This clinical practicum provides students with the opportunity to gain additional knowledge and experience in specialty practice areas with relevance to pediatric primary care. Required of pediatric nurse practitioner students in the final year of specialization, usually taken during the spring term. A second term may be taken as an elective in the final year with permission of the course instructor and faculty adviser. Four and one-half hours of clinical practice per week and eight hours of clinical conference.
title: Specialty Pediatric Clinical Practice
subject: NURS

description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time, examining how new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea; whether happiness should be a goal in life; the relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Happiness
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to the history and methods of philosophical reflection and inquiry. Exploration of several perennial philosophical issues and the distinctive ways of addressing these issues through a close reading of historical texts and group discussion. Readings include selections from the works of Plato, Aristotle, Hume, Kant, Mill, and twentieth-century philosophers. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Introduction to Philosophy
subject: PHIL

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee $85. Offered in Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30233) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRN: 30234).
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
subject: PHIL

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee $85. Offered in Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30233) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRN: 30234).
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to problems and methods in the philosophy of law. The nature of law and legal authority; political questions regarding the nature of rights and limitations on freedom; issues in criminal law, tort law, and contract law. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
subject: PHIL

description: Overview of central ethical questions within the global arena. Topics include international governance, just war, human rights, genocide, global justice, humanitarian intervention, and economic sanctions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: International Ethics
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, the self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Eastern Philosophy
subject: PHIL

description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Environmental Ethics
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non–science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 25 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PHYS

subject: PHYS

description: Issues of liberty, equality, and justice considered from within the Western tradition of political philosophy. Readings from Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill and contemporary authors. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PLSC

description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PLSC

description: This six-week course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities Global Summer Program. Two students from each partner university, including two from Yale, will be admitted to this course. Partial funding is provided for all students enrolled. The course will cover the mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and of the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 29 - August 8.
title: Foreign Policy and International Law
subject: PLSC

description: American grand strategy since the collapse of the Soviet Union. The ability of the United States to project its power around the world. Constraints on and challenges to American power in the international political system. The effect of nuclear weapons on the workings of a unipolar world. The possible emergence of peer competitors in the future. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PLSC

description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PLSC

description: Questions about how journalism influences public policy, the traditional model of print journalism versus advances in technology and changes in our culture. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PLSC

description: Topics in the history, theory, and realities of crime and punishment in the contemporary United States. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

What the term "terrorism" denotes and why and when it is used; U.S. law regarding material support for terrorism; the targeted killing of persons in a global battlefield; how terrorism compares morally to other forms of political violence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

Evolutionary theories of the origins of emotion; culture, sex and gender influences; emotion and morality; brain basis of emotion; sleeping and feeling; relationship between emotion and thinking; love and relationships; development of emotion; animal vs. human emotion; abnormal emotions in mental illness; and happiness. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee $85. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PSYC

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee $85. Offered in Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30226) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRN: 30227).

Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee $85. Topics include cognitive abilities, personality, psychopathology, and sexual orientation. Emphasis on identifying ethical dilemmas raised by emerging findings in behavioral genetics, how such findings are portrayed by the media, and what implications they have for advancing theories, research methods, clinical practice, and policy. Recommended preparation: PSYC 110, or an equivalent introduction to Psychology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. This course explores the cultural history of the imperial Russian capital, founded by Peter the Great in the early eighteenth century as a window on Europe. Since then, the city has been seen to embody all the contradictions of Russia: East vs. West, imperial grandeur vs. the pathos of the little man, nature vs. civilization, free will vs. fate. The course considers the semiotics of Petersburg through a careful reading of selected literary texts, both prose and poetry, including Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky, Blok, Bely, Gumilev, Akhmatova, Mandelstam, Khlebnikov, Mayakovsky, Kharms, and others, as well as some works of literary and cultural criticism. The classroom sessions are complimented with a rich selection of excursions and tours in and around St. Petersburg. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS 130/140 or RUSS S150/151. For more information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see RUSS S130/140 or RUSS S150/151. Course dates: June 2 - July 29.
title: Russian Culture
subject: RUSS

description: A close reading of Dostoevsky's most philosophical work, The Brothers Karamazov, alongside works by Russian religious philosophers, including Solovyov, Rozanov, and Berdyaev, all of whom consider the religious aspects of Dostoevsky's masterpiece. Examination of the role of Eastern Orthodox thought in the Russian literary tradition. Readings and discussion in English. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Dostoevsky and Russian Religious Thought
subject: RUSS

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Students will have the opportunity to study and be in class with local students from St. Xavier's University. Critical engagement with contemporary Indian politics, society, culture, and religion through an intensive and immersive study in Mumbai, one of the largest cities in the world. Topics include: urban poverty, urban town planning, housing problems, sanitation, cultural politics, religious and sectarian violence, caste politics, class ghettoization, communal violence, migration, urban-rural divide, Bollywood and popular culture. Students choose ANTH or SAST credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For more information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: May 31 - July 4.
title: Bombay: City, Society and Culture
subject: SAST

description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design, and data interpretation, through lectures, readings, and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions for preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations, highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative information. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. June 9 - August 9.
title: Scientific Research: Process and Presentation
subject: SCIE

description: A sociological approach to the study of sex and gender, focusing on how these categories are socially constructed, and how and why they matter for individuals and societies. Topics include the relationship between sex and gender; sex/gender difference and competing explanations for sexual inequalities; gender and work; sex and sexuality in society; masculinity, gender, and sports; and the intersection of gender with other social categories such as race/ethnicity and class. The readings cover various stages of the life course and examine how sex and gender shape individual experiences and produce social inequalities. They address children's upbringing, educational experiences, experiences in various workplaces, parenting, and health and reproduction. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Sex and Gender in Society
subject: SOCY

description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation-states. Mechanisms and challenges involved in incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Global Public Health
subject: SOCY

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime? What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality? What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy? This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system. Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice. Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: SOCY

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,350. Course dates: June 29 - August 2.

description: Offered in Buenos Aires, Argentina. This is an advanced Spanish theater workshop that explores the dynamics of figurative language through the close reading of original Spanish and Latin American dramatic texts. The purpose of the course is to improve your language and theatrical skills through the reading, writing, analysis, and performance of selected scenes and plays from the Middle Age to the present. This will result not only in the increase of your language proficiency in Spanish, but also in a better understanding of the dynamics of Hispanic theater. Students will act in different scenes, prepare monologues, attend live performances of Argentine theater, and will be part of a final performance on stage. Prerequisite: SPAN 150 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Buenos Aires, room and board costs in Argentina, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: May 24 - June 28.
title: Theater and Poetry Workshop
subject: SPAN

description: Four weeks in New Haven and four weeks in Lima, Peru. The historical, social, and cultural development of Peru from pre-Columbian times to the present. Peruvian history; the culture and character of Peru and of its capital, Lima; architecture, art, gastronomic history, immigration, and ethnicity. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, music, and visual arts. Conducted in Spanish. Must be taken concurrently with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.
title: Cultural Studies of Peru
subject: SPAN

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Bilbao. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Classes will be held in the headquarters of the University of Deusto, located opposite the statuary and facing the Guggenheim Museum. Founded in 1886, the university continues to be one of the most important institutions of higher education of the Basque Country and Spain. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.
title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
subject: SPAN

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Quito. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Ecuador from Pre-Columbian times to the present. Presented through a variety of materials (literary texts, essays, films, music, visual arts). Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Quito, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.
title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to Present
subject: SPAN

description: An introduction to statistical reasoning. Topics include controlled experiments and observational studies; histograms and scatterplots, averages and standard deviations; measurement error, the normal approximation; correlation and regression; probability and chance variation; sampling, the Gallup Poll and Current Population Survey; tests of significance. Focus on understanding concepts rather than mathematical manipulation. No formal mathematical prerequisite. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Introduction to Statistics
subject: STAT

description: An examination of forces shaping American cities and strategies for dealing with them. Topics include housing, commercial development, parks, zoning, urban renewal, landmark preservation, new towns, and suburbs. Includes games, simulated problems, fieldwork, lectures, and discussion as well as field trips in New Haven and to New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Introduction to the Study of the City
subject: STCY

description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Credit only on completion of SWAH S140. Prerequisite: SWAH 120b (Elementary Kiswahili II) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Mombasa, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information contact the instructor at bierstek@msu.edu or visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.
title: Intermediate Kiswahili I
subject: SWAH

description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at bierstek@msu.edu or visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.
title: Intermediate Kiswahili II
subject: SWAH

description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of eastern and central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140b or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Kenya, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Course dates: May 31 - July 12.
title: Advanced Kiswahili
subject: SWAH

description: Study of drama, performance, and dance-theater created in the last ten years, with special attention to works produced in 2013 and 2014. Readings from both published and unpublished American and British plays, contemporary criticism, interviews, and essays by the artists themselves. Video of works created by companies such as Elevator Repair Service, Les Freres Corbusier, and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Will include attendance of productions in and around New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Theater Now
subject: THST

description: Offered Online. Twentieth-century American drama and theater. Modernist innovations of Eugene O'Neill and the Provincetown Players, the socially committed drama of the Depression-era Group Theater and the Federal Theater Project, the rise of musical theater, Thornton Wilder's metatheatricality, Tennessee Williams's staging of sexual ambivalence, and Arthur Miller's parables of American ambition. Readings in contemporary drama by Edward Albee, David Mamet, Sam Shepard, Maria Irene Fornes, and Suzan-Lori Parks. Discussion of changing acting approaches and a survey of experimental theater. When possible, readings will be supplemented with viewings of performances on video. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Modern American Drama
subject: THST

description: A sociological approach to the study of sex and gender, focusing on how these categories are socially constructed, and how and why they matter for individuals and societies. Topics include the relationship between sex and gender; sex/gender difference and competing explanations for sexual inequalities; gender and work; sex and sexuality in society; masculinity, gender, and sports; and the intersection of gender with other social categories such as race/ethnicity and class. The readings cover various stages of the life course and examine how sex and gender shape individual experiences and produce social inequalities. They address children's upbringing, educational experiences, experiences in various workplaces, parenting, and health and reproduction. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.
title: Sex and Gender in Society
subject: WGSS

description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to Peabody Museum, Beinecke Library, Yale Farm, and Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.
title: Women, Food and Culture
subject: WGSS

description: Introduction to the roles of women in ancient Egyptian, Mesopotamian, and Aegean society, as reflected in painting, sculpture, and decorative arts, as well as in the earliest known writings of women. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4
title: Women in the Western World
subject: WGSS
